awd_titl_txt: Carbonate system dynamics and biogeochemistry in a changing Arctic
awd_abstract_narration:
The Arctic is an important sink for atmospheric carbon dioxide, a powerful greenhouse gas. However, as the Arctic warms and the extent of summer sea ice declines (in a few decades, it is expected the summer Arctic Ocean will be ice free), it is not clear the degree to which this will change. The investigators will explore how carbon dioxide chemistry along the ice margins (marginal ice zone: MIZ) waters differ from that in the open ocean. Taking water samples on the RV Sikuliaq between May 20 to June 14, 2021, from the Bering sea to the MIZ in the Chukchi Sea, the investigators will measure several components of the carbon dioxide system in seawater, including the total concentration of carbon, and determine how much acidity the water can neutralize. This study will provide a better understanding of the complexities of arctic biogeochemistry and its changing role in carbon sequestration and ocean acidification in a warmer world. The investigators will produce a podcast series during the research cruise to share their experiences and findings for community science.

Arctic Ocean summer sea ice is predicted to retreat such that in just a few decades the new norm will be ice-free summers. Taking water samples on the RV Sikuliaq between May 20 to June 14, 2021, from the Bering sea to the marginal ice zone in the Chukchi Sea, the area where open water becomes progressively more ice-covered (and ice melt is a significant signal), presents a unique opportunity to better understand the complexities in arctic biogeochemistry and its changing role in carbon sequestration as the summer ice edge recedes. By examining the internal consistency of the carbonate system/models, the work will lead to an improved understanding of the controls on ocean acidification and ocean-atmosphere CO2 exchange. The investigators will examine important carbonate system measurements such as dissolved organic and inorganic carbon, that when coupled with parallel mercury measurements being taken on the Sikuliaq, will improve our understanding of the relationships between dissolved elemental Hg and DIC in the Arctic, both in the open water and under the ice. The investigators will generate hands-on videos and materials for citizen science groups with a focus on polar regions. Finally, the investigators will create a cruise podcast series that will comprise five to ten minute podcasts for the public on the changing arctic, what it’s like to be a young oceanographer, and themes related to the study.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Arctic Marginal Ice Zone Alkalinity (AMIZA) was dedicated to evaluating the carbonate system dynamics in an extreme environment that is rapidly changing to make better predictions of how the Arctic carbon dioxide sink may change in a warming climate. The project was very successful in that it captured the spring period of melt onset that is not well studied. AMIZA has resulted in 3 peer reviewed papers that capture the timescales and magnitude of important unknowns in the Arctic carbonate system. AMIZA resulted in the first direct benthic flux measurement of inroganic carbon (DIC) to overlying waters in the Bering and Chukchi Seas and quantified both the range of DIC efflux and the rapid reventilation of the water column (over 2-4 days) as the ice melted and receeded. The project also identified significant anomalies in the boron to salinity ratios of ice and brine from those used in traditional carbonate system analyses to constrain carbonate speciiation. Finally, AMIZA quantified water column carbonate dynamics including aragonite saturation and how rapidly this changes when ice receeds. Over a timescale of two weeks, chlorophyll blooms came and went and the newly exposed water column reverted to steady state conditions. AMIZA has led to more studies comparing the eastern and western Arctic to further understand these trends across the Arctic Ocean.

Broader Impacts: AMIZA has resulted in several podcasts and art creations that have reached general public audiences and has served to raise awareness of the rapid changes the Arctic is undergoing. The roject also was key to the doctoral research of two graduate students who have successfully completed their PhDs. AMIZA has identified new uncertainties and fluxes in the carbonate system that will also be useful across disciplines working on polar and global processes.
